title: Pittaja Jwara â€” Acute fever with Pitta predominance
subject: Kayachikitsa
stem: 34-year-old female with 2 days of high fever, severe thirst, irritability, and yellowish discoloration of urine.

history.symptom_quality: High fever, intense thirst, burning sensation in body
history.aggravation_relief: Worse at night, slightly better after cold drinks
history.bowel_urine: Loose stools x1, urine dark yellow and reduced quantity
history.sleep: Disturbed due to restlessness and body heat

onRequestExam.general: Patient is restless, appears dehydrated, tongue red with yellow coating
onRequestExam.abdomen: Soft, mild tenderness in epigastric region

labsOnOrder.LFT: Mildly elevated bilirubin (1.8 mg/dL), ALT 45 U/L (slightly raised)
labsOnOrder.Urine_routine: Yellow colored, specific gravity 1.025, trace protein

items.text: Elicit onset, duration, and character of fever (SOCRATES approach)
Ask about fluid intake, thirst, and signs of dehydration
Inquire about aggravating/relieving factors and Pittaja symptoms
Perform Nadi Pariksha and recognize Pittaja pulse characteristics
Assess for Pittaja signs (tongue coating, skin warmth, thirst)
Order relevant investigations (CBC, LFT, malaria screen)
Initiate cooling measures, ORS, consider antipyretics and referral if severe
Explain diagnosis and management plan clearly; provide reassurance

mcqs.stem: A patient with Pittaja Jwara typically presents with:
choices: Cold intolerance and preference for warm drinks
Intense thirst and preference for cold drinks
mcqs.rationale: Pittaja Jwara is characterized by intense burning sensation, high fever, and excessive thirst with preference for cold drinks. The patient experiences aggravation of Pitta dosha.

mcqs.stem: In Nadi Pariksha, a Pittaja pulse is characterized by:
choices: Slow and deep like a frog
Fast and thin like a crow
Irregular and moving like a snake
mcqs.rationale: Pittaja Nadi is described as fast (rapid) and thin (light), similar to the movement of a crow (Kaka gati). This reflects the increased metabolic rate in Pitta conditions.

mcqs.stem: First-line cooling measure for Pittaja Jwara includes:
choices: Oral rehydration with cooling herbs like Usheera
mcqs.rationale: Pittaja conditions require cooling therapies. ORS with cooling herbs like Usheera (Vetiver) helps reduce Pitta and prevent dehydration. Heat-inducing measures would aggravate Pitta.
